questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of weakness of his left leg for the past hour. He was unable to get out of bed that morning. His pants are soaked with urine. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include enalapril, carvedilol, aspirin, and simvastatin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows equal pupils that are reactive to light. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the left lower extremity. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left. Sensation is decreased in the left lower extremity. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time and has a flat affect. When asked to count backwards from 20, he stops after counting to 17. When asked to name 10 words beginning with the letter “d,” he stops after naming two words. Fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) may manifest with urinary incontinence and behavioral changes including a flattened affect and abulia. However, this condition is a gradually progressive disease, unlike the acute presentation in this patient. Although patients with NPH may have a feeling of weakness and numbness, true sensory deficits or lower limb weakness severe enough to impair movement are not typically seen. Instead, gait abnormalities (typically a shuffling, wide-based gait) are usually the earliest sign.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

B) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery would result in lateral medullary syndrome, which is characterized by hoarseness, dysphagia, ipsilateral ataxia, ipsilateral preganglionic Horner's syndrome, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensations over the face ipsilaterally and in the contralateral side of the body. Urinary incontinence, motor deficits, and clinical features of frontal lobe damage are not usually seen.

C) INCORRECT:

A large infarct in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) may result in abulia as well as sensory and motor deficits. However, neurologic deficits would occur in the right limb rather than the left one and are usually more prominent in the upper limb and trunk when compared to the lower limb. Patients with a left MCA stroke would also have dysphasia.
Image Description:

A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:

– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

D) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery results in infarction of the lateral caudal pons and/or ischemia in the territory of the labyrinthine artery. Patients present with ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss, ipsilateral ataxia, ipsilateral preganglionic Horner's syndrome, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensations over the face ipsilaterally and in the contralateral side of the body. Urinary incontinence, motor deficits, and clinical features of frontal lobe damage (e.g., abulia, flat affect) are not usually seen.

E) INCORRECT:

A large infarct in the territory of the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) can cause abulia and sensory and motor neurologic deficits on the left side of the body. However, neurologic deficits are usually more prominent in the upper limb and trunk than in the lower limb. Also, a patient with a massive right MCA stroke would present with left hemineglect (if the right hemisphere is nondominant) or aphasia (if the right hemisphere is dominant).

F) CORRECT:

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the anteromedial cortex, including the medial part of the frontal lobe and parietal lobe. These areas provide motor and sensory innervation of the lower extremities as well as control of micturition. Occlusion of the postcommunal segment (distal to the circle of Willis) of the right ACA typically results in upper motor neuron weakness manifesting with a contralateral positive Babinski sign, sensory deficits of the contralateral lower limb, and urinary incontinence. Signs of frontal lobe damage (e.g., abulia), as well as aphasia and limb apraxia, may also be present.

G) INCORRECT:

A right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion typically results in left homonymous hemianopia, not urinary incontinence and frontal lobe signs such as abulia. Larger PCA infarcts may occasionally cause hemisensory loss and/or hemiparesis. However, other features such as prosopagnosia (in individuals where the right hemisphere is the nondominant one) would also be expected.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

H) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) manifests with urinary incontinence and abulia with sensory loss and upper motor neuron weakness in the lower limb (which causes a positive Babinski sign). However, the neurologic deficits in a left ACA stroke would appear in the right lower limb, not the left one.

I) INCORRECT:

Encephalitis that predominantly affects the medial temporal lobe is characteristic of herpes simplex encephalitis, which may manifest with focal neurologic deficits. However, in almost all patients, the onset of neurologic deficits would be preceded by fever, headache, and/or vomiting. Other clinical features such as memory loss, emotional lability, and/or dysphasia would also be present.

J) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive encephalopathy is a hypertensive emergency that occurs in patients with a mean arterial pressure >180 mm Hg and can cause neurologic deficits and nonlocalizing signs of cerebral edema, such as severe headache, nausea, and/or vomiting. Furthermore, hypertensive encephalopathy typically has an insidious onset, in contrast to the acute onset in this patient. Other features such as findings of grade IV hypertensive retinopathy on fundoscopy (flame-shaped hemorrhage, papilledema, and/or cotton wool spots) would also be present.

K) INCORRECT:

A left posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion typically results in right homonymous hemianopia, not urinary incontinence and frontal lobe signs such as abulia. Larger PCA infarcts may occasionally cause hemisensory loss and/or hemiparesis. However, in a patient with a large left PCA infarct, the contralateral (right not left) limb would be affected, and other clinical features such as alexia without agraphia would be present.
questions.hint: This patient has sudden-onset neurologic symptoms. An inability to complete goal-directed tests such as counting backward from 20 or naming words starting with the letter “d” together with a flat affect indicates abulia, which is usually the result of damage to the frontal lobe.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of weakness in her right arm, leg, and face. Her husband says that she was finishing her breakfast when suddenly her right leg and arm “stopped working properly.” She tried to talk to him but her speech was incoherent. For the past 4 months, she has been more anxious than usual and experienced dizziness on several occasions. She used to exercise regularly but had to give up her exercise routine 3 months ago because of generalized fatigue, and lightheadedness and shortness of breath with exertion. She has a history of hypertension. She takes lisinopril daily and alprazolam as needed. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is a tax accountant and has had increased stress at work recently. On presentation, she is alert and fully oriented; her speech is normal. The patient's pants are soaked with urine. On neurologic examination, she has a slight right facial droop and 4/5 muscle strength in the right arm and leg. Sensation is slightly diminished over the right side of the face and right arm and leg. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Irregularly irregular R-R intervals on electrocardiogram
Ruptured saccular aneurysm on CT angiography of the head
Double lumen of the left-sided carotid artery on duplex ultrasound
Intraparenchymal hyperdensity on CT scan of the head

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Irregularly irregular rhythm and absent P waves on ECG are characteristic of atrial fibrillation (Afib). Although the classic signs of Afib include tachycardia and an irregularly irregular pulse, some individuals are asymptomatic or present only with subtle signs of arrhythmia (e.g., palpitations, dizziness, lightheadedness, fatigue, and dyspnea). The uncoordinated atrial contractions lead to blood stasis in the left atrium and atrial appendage, which significantly increases the risk of clot formation and thromboembolic complications. Dislodged emboli can clog several different arteries simultaneously and result in embolic ischemic stroke. Individuals with embolic stroke typically experience maximum severity of symptoms at onset, followed by rapid improvement if the emboli migrate outward allowing arterial recanalization. Embolic stroke from a cardiac source often affects young or middle-aged people with cardiac disease, whereas thrombotic or embolic stroke due to atherosclerosis is more common in older adults with risk factors for atherosclerosis.

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to calculate the risk of stroke in patients with Afib. This patient's score is 2 points (female sex, history of hypertension), which puts her at intermediate risk for stroke.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm (examples of the irregular R-R intervals are indicated by red arrows)

– Average ventricular rate ∼ 84/min (14 QRS complexes can be seen on the 10-second rhythm strip)

– No discernable P waves

– Narrow QRS complexes (examples indicated by green lines)

– Normal cardiac axis

These findings are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

B) INCORRECT:

A ruptured saccular aneurysm resulting in subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) leads to hemorrhagic stroke. SAH classically manifests with severe headaches (often described by patients as the worst headache they have ever experienced) with a hyperacute onset, other meningeal signs, and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., nausea, vomiting) in addition to focal neurological deficits. In patients with hemorrhagic stroke, these deficits typically worsen as the hematoma expands. In this patient whose symptoms have rapidly improved, an embolic stroke, not a hemorrhagic stroke, is more likely; therefore, another finding would be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Valvular vegetations on transthoracic echocardiography are characteristic of bacterial endocarditis (BE), which can cause septic embolization and result in an embolic stroke. Subacute BE can manifest with lightheadedness and dyspnea on exertion for weeks to months. However, most patients with BE present with constitutional symptoms, as well as extracardiac manifestations, such as petechiae, splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, and/or Roth spots. In addition, BE typically develops in patients with a history of structural cardiac disease (e.g., rheumatic heart disease, aortic stenosis), prosthetic valves, IV drug use, intravascular devices (e.g., IV catheter), or poor dental hygiene.

D) INCORRECT:

A double lumen of the left-sided carotid artery on duplex ultrasound is consistent with carotid artery dissection (CAD), which can lead to ischemic stroke. However, nonischemic features due to expanding hematoma would be expected, such as ipsilateral headache, facial/neck pain, Horner syndrome, and/or tinnitus. Finally, CAD is typically caused by penetrating or blunt trauma, which this patient has no history of.

E) INCORRECT:

An intraparenchymal hyperdensity on head CT suggests intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH). Given this patient's history of hypertension, the index of suspicion for spontaneous ICH should be high. However, ICH causes hemorrhagic stroke typically manifesting with headaches (caused by meningeal irritation/traction) and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., nausea, vomiting) in addition to focal neurological deficits. In patients with hemorrhagic stroke, these deficits typically worsen as the hematoma expands. In this patient whose symptoms have rapidly improved, an embolic stroke, not a hemorrhagic stroke, is more likely; therefore, another finding would be expected.
questions.hint: Right-sided weakness and numbness in the upper and lower limbs, urinary incontinence, and aphasia (incoherent speech) suggest stroke affecting several different vascular territories: the left anterior cerebral artery and left middle cerebral artery. These features in combination with rapid clinical improvement after symptom onset suggest a specific etiology of stroke, which is further supported by the history of fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and lightheadedness.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after his wife noticed that the right side of his face was drooping during breakfast. He had difficulty putting on his shirt and shoes before coming to the hospital. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. He has an implanted insulin pump for blood sugar control. His medications are enalapril and atorvastatin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He drinks one glass of wine daily. He is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. Examination shows equal and reactive pupils with gaze deviation towards the left. Visual field testing shows right-sided homonymous hemianopia. Neurologic examination shows a right facial droop. Muscle strength and sensation are decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. Plantar reflex testing shows an extensor response on the right side. Speech is dysarthric. There is a bruit on the left side of the neck. Funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count, coagulation profile, and serum concentrations of glucose and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Noncontrast CT scan of the head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain is an appropriate diagnostic modality in the initial work-up of suspected stroke. However, this patient has an implanted insulin pump, which could be adversely affected by the MRI scanner.

B) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture (LP) may be used in the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which typically manifests with a thunderclap headache that rapidly progresses to nausea, vomiting, cardiovascular dysfunction, coma, and then death. SAH can cause stroke, but as this patient lacks the characteristic history of sudden-onset, severe headache that is present in almost all patients with SAH, this diagnosis is less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is used to identify carotid stenosis, for which this patient is at high risk (as suggested by carotid bruit and likely thromboembolic stroke), but the diagnosis and treatment of this patient's suspected stroke takes priority over confirming carotid stenosis; confirmation of carotid stenosis would not affect acute stroke management. Duplex ultrasonography would likely be performed later on in management, once the acute phase of the stroke has been managed.

D) INCORRECT:

Cerebral angiography (i.e., CTA or MRA) can be used in the diagnosis of stroke and to facilitate in-situ treatment (i.e., mechanical thrombectomy). However, because angiography uses intravasal contrast, hemorrhage should be excluded first. Therefore, a different step in management is more appropriate at this time.

E) CORRECT:

An emergency, noncontrast CT scan of the head is the preferred imaging technique to rule out intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) in patients with suspected stroke and should be carried out before other management (e.g., thrombolysis). Additionally, a CT scan may detect signs of ischemia (e.g., hypoattenuation or large clots in a blood vessel). CT scans are fast and can significantly reduce the morbidity and mortality of stroke. Although MRI can be used as an alternative for diagnosis, it is inappropriate in this patient because it could adversely affect his implanted insulin pump. If initial imaging is inconclusive but clinical suspicion for ICH is high (e.g., thunderclap headache), a lumbar puncture may be performed to evaluate for signs of the condition (e.g., erythrocytes) in the cerebrospinal fluid.

This patient has several risk factors for stroke (i.e., diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and smoking), and the carotid bruit suggests a thromboembolic ischemic stroke. This patient's presentation (right-sided facial droop, sensory and motor deficit in the right upper and lower extremities, right-sided Babinski sign, gaze deviation towards the left, right-sided homonymous hemianopia, dysarthria) is consistent with ischemia in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery.
Image Description:

BMP: basic metabolic panel
BP: blood pressure
CBC: complete blood count
CT: computed tomography
DW-MRI: diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging
ECG: electrocardiogram
ICP: intracranial pressure
IV: intravenous
MRI: magnetic resonance imaging
NIHSS: National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale
POC: point-of-care
questions.hint: Acute onset of focal neurologic symptoms should raise concern for stroke, which is a neurologic emergency that requires fast workup.

questions.text: A noncontrast CT scan of the patient's head is performed immediately and the result is shown. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 174/102 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical decompression (e.g., craniotomy) is indicated to relieve intracranial hypertension in patients with hemorrhagic stroke if there are signs of brain herniation (e.g., Cushing's triad), brainstem compression, obstructive hydrocephalus, or hemorrhage extension > 3 cm. Although this patient's symptoms could be caused by a hemorrhagic stroke, his CT scan rules it out.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

A large hyperdense hematoma (green overlay) in the posterior aspect of the left cerebral hemisphere is accompanied by hypodense edema (red overlay), effacement of the occipital horn of the left lateral ventricle, and midline shift (dashed line and arrowheads).

ROH: right occipital horn

B) INCORRECT:

Hypotensive agents (e.g., labetalol) are indicated for ischemic stroke in patients who are good candidates for reperfusion therapy and have blood pressure > 185/110 mm Hg (up to 220/120 mm Hg can be tolerated in those who do not undergo reperfusion therapy). This patient's blood pressure is not high enough to warrant reduction, and lowering it might worsen his condition by decreasing cerebral perfusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is indicated for ischemic stroke and should be administered within 24–48 hours of the event. This patient currently requires a different step in management that contraindicates antiplatelet therapy for an additional 24 hours.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids (e.g., methylprednisolone) can reduce brain inflammation and edema, which may develop as a result of ischemia. However, glucocorticoids are currently not recommended in the initial acute treatment of stroke, because there is no conclusive evidence that they actually improve outcomes. Furthermore, glucocorticoid use increases the risk of GI bleeding, infection, and hyperglycemia.

E) CORRECT:

Intravenous thrombolytics (e.g., alteplase) are indicated for ischemic stroke in patients without contraindications for thrombolytic therapy (e.g., active bleeding, blood pressure > 185/110 mm Hg). This patient has signs of left-sided stroke with symptoms that began less than 1 hour ago and no evidence of hemorrhage on CT scan, so he is eligible for alteplase therapy. A hyperdense MCA sign indicates an acute thromboembolic occlusion of the MCA, which is almost certainly the cause of his symptoms. Thrombolytics are typically initiated within 3–4.5 hours of symptom onset. If the time of symptom onset is unknown or > 4.5 hours ago, eligibility for thrombolysis is evaluated under specialist guidance as the risks of the procedure might exceed its benefits. All patients regardless of whether they receive thrombolytic therapy should also be evaluated to determine eligibility for mechanical thrombectomy. Antiplatelet therapy (typically with aspirin) should be administered 24 hours after thrombolytic therapy.
Image Description:

BMP: basic metabolic panel
BP: blood pressure
CBC: complete blood count
CT: computed tomography
DW-MRI: diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging
ECG: electrocardiogram
ICP: intracranial pressure
IV: intravenous
MRI: magnetic resonance imaging
NIHSS: National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale
POC: point-of-care

F) INCORRECT:

Surgical clipping is indicated for subarachnoid hemorrhage due to ruptured cerebral aneurysm. This patient's history is not consistent with subarachnoid hemorrhage (e.g., thunderclap headache), and his CT scan does not show any signs of ruptured aneurysm.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Regions of high attenuation (green overlay) in the interpeduncular cistern, Sylvian fissures, and left posterior fossa represent acute subarachnoid hemorrhage. The cerebellar tentorium (red overlay) should not be misinterpreted as blood.
questions.hint: The CT scan shows a left hyperdense middle cerebral artery (MCA) sign.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter because of left-sided weakness for 1 hour. She does not have headache or blurring of vision. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, type 2 diabetes, and coronary artery disease. She has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Her medications include atorvastatin, amlodipine, metformin, and aspirin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min and regular, and blood pressure is 168/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a left facial droop. Muscle strength is decreased on the left side. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ on the left. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration as well as two-point discrimination are normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Atherosclerosis of the internal carotid artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A stroke due to carotid artery stenosis (CAS) is usually an ischemic cortical infarct of the middle cerebral artery or, less commonly, anterior cerebral artery due to atheroembolism. However, a right-sided cortical infarct that is large enough to cause weakness in the entire left half of the body would likely also cause other additional symptoms such as aphasia, hemineglect, frontal lobe defects, and/or deficits of both somatosensory (e.g., pain, light touch) and cortical sensations (e.g., stereognosis, two-point discrimination). Moreover, patients with CAS often have a history of amaurosis fugax or transient ischemic attacks and a carotid bruit on neck auscultation.

B) INCORRECT:

The rupture of an intracranial (berry) aneurysm typically results in subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which commonly manifests with a sudden-onset severe headache (“worst headache of my life”), rapidly worsening nausea and/or vomiting, and clinical features of meningism (e.g., neck rigidity). Although patients with SAH may develop hemiparesis due to tentorial herniation, additional findings such as altered mental status, elevated intracranial pressure, and palsies of the oculomotor and abducens nerve would also be expected.

C) CORRECT:

Lipohyalinosis of the lenticulostriate arteries is the most common cause of pure motor strokes and typically affects the posterior limb of the internal capsule, in which motor fibers are densely packed. This region of the internal capsule is supplied by lenticulostriate arteries, which are narrow end-arteries without collateral circulation that branch directly from large arteries. Hypertension is the most important risk factor for lacunar infarcts. Other risk factors include diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and smoking.

D) INCORRECT:

Dissection of the right vertebral artery typically results in right lateral medullary syndrome, which manifests with left-sided weakness. However, this condition is also associated with features such as vertigo, ipsilateral hearing loss, ataxia, dysarthria, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation. Patients with vertebral artery dissection usually also complain of neck pain and/or occipital headache. Furthermore, they are usually younger (mean age approx. 45 years) and often report a history of trauma or sports injury.

E) INCORRECT:

An embolus from the left atrium is the most common cause of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Although this patient has many of the risk factors for atrial fibrillation (i.e., increased age, hypertension, smoking, coronary artery disease), she does not have evidence of this condition on examination (e.g., an irregularly irregular pulse, an apex-pulse deficit). Moreover, cardiac embolism is a rare cause of lacunar strokes.
questions.hint: This patient presents with weakness of the face, upper limb, and lower limb on the left side without associated sensory dysfunction, which suggests a pure motor lacunar infarct.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a coworker for right arm weakness and numbness. The symptoms started suddenly 2 hours ago. His coworker also noticed that the patient's face appears to droop on the right side and that his speech sounds slurred. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and peripheral arterial disease. He works as a partner at a law firm and has been under more stress than usual lately. His father died of a stroke at age 70. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years. He drinks two pints (1130 mL) of whiskey each week. He takes aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, and metformin daily. He is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 104 kg (229 lb); BMI is 37 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 143/92 mm Hg. He is fully alert and oriented. Neurologic examination shows asymmetry of the face with droop of the lips on the right. There is 3/5 strength in right wrist flexion and extension and right finger abduction. Sensation to light touch and pinprick is reduced throughout the right arm. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus have an increased risk for early-onset atherosclerosis of large vessels, which is a result of nonspecific diabetic vessel damage. Although type 2 diabetes mellitus is an important risk factor for stroke, it is not the strongest one.

B) CORRECT:

Hypertension is the strongest predisposing factor for both ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke. Ischemic stroke is primarily caused by large artery atherosclerosis (for which hypertension is a major risk factor), whereas hemorrhagic stroke is most often due to rupture of vessels that have been damaged by chronic arterial hypertension. The most significant nonmodifiable risk factor is age > 65 years. Other important predisposing factors for ischemic stroke include conditions that increase the thromboembolic risk such as diabetes mellitus, atrial fibrillation, and carotid artery stenosis. Risk factors for hemorrhagic stroke include conditions that lead to vascular damage, such as vasculitis, malignancy, and previous ischemic stroke.

This patient's risk for hypertension-related stroke is further elevated because his blood pressure is not optimally controlled. According to current recommendations by the American Heart Association and American College of Cardiology, blood pressure should not exceed a maximum of < 130/80 mm Hg in patients with diabetes mellitus.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

The right cerebral hemisphere is hypodense (green overlay) in the distributions of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries. The presence of thromboembolic material has caused the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) to appear hyperdense (hyperdense-MCA sign; white arrowhead). Cerebral edema has resulted in effacement of the sulci and the loss of differentiation between the medulla and cortex. Accompanying mass effect has compressed the right lateral ventricle (red overlay) and caused slight contralateral shift of the midline (indicated by white arrow and dashed line).

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive, regular consumption of alcohol increases the risk for a number of conditions, which are themselves risk factors for stroke. Alcohol can raise blood pressure, promote insulin resistance, cause obesity, and trigger atrial fibrillation with an increased risk for thromboembolic events. Alcohol hepatotoxicity (e.g., cirrhosis) can also lead to insufficient synthesis of coagulation factors and promote hemorrhagic events. This patient's alcohol use considerably increases his risk for stroke but is not the single strongest predisposing factor.

D) INCORRECT:

A positive family history for stroke suggests a possible genetic predisposition for the development of risk factors for stroke, e.g., familial hypercholesterolemia. However, to what degree an individual is affected physically by a genetic predisposition varies greatly and may not significantly increase the risk for stroke. A positive family history is therefore not the single strongest predisposing factor for stroke.

E) INCORRECT:

How psychological or emotional stress, especially if experienced over long periods of time, increases the risk for stroke is complex and still subject to research. Likely pathomechanisms include inflammatory processes directly affecting the arteries, as well as increased secretion of proinflammatory cytokines which promote the development of atherosclerosis. However, the physical impact of stress varies greatly from person to person and does not have the strongest association with the development of stroke.

F) INCORRECT:

Obesity is both an independent risk factor for cardiovascular disease, including stroke, and is closely associated with a variety of other cardiovascular risk factors. While an important modifiable risk factor, obesity is not the strongest risk factor for stroke.

G) INCORRECT:

Hyperlipidemia can contribute to the development of atherosclerosis by forming plaques in the tunica intima of arterial walls. Atherosclerosis, in turn, causes intraluminal narrowing and obstruction of arteries and may lead to stroke. While an important risk factor for stroke, it is not the strongest one.

H) INCORRECT:

Smoking is an important risk factor for stroke, especially for ischemic stroke and subarachnoid hemorrhage. Smoking causes vascular damage, most likely due to an increase in platelet aggregation and fibrinogen levels, a reduction of HDL cholesterol levels, and direct vascular toxic effects of certain tobacco compounds. Although this patient has a considerable risk of vascular damage due to his long history of tobacco use, smoking alone does not have the strongest association with the development of stroke.
questions.hint: This patient presents with sudden-onset focal neurologic symptoms (right arm numbness and weakness, facial droop, slurred speech) which is suggestive of stroke in the area of the left middle cerebral artery.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty speaking. The symptoms began abruptly one hour ago while he was having breakfast with his wife. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include pravastatin, lisinopril, metformin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg. He is right-handed. The patient speaks in short, simple sentences, and has difficulty repeating sequences of words. He can follow simple instructions. Right facial droop is present. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left, and there is a mild right-sided pronator drift downwards. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Occlusion of the right penetrating arteries
Occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery
Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries
Dissection of the right vertebral artery
Occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery
Rupture of right posterior cerebral artery malformation
Occlusion of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Rupture of left posterior cerebral artery malformation
Dissection of the left vertebral artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which manifests with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Broca aphasia and right-sided weakness are not consistent with lateral medullary syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Ischemia to the right posterior limb of the internal capsule, due to occlusion of right penetrating arteries, would cause left-sided, not right-sided weakness. Furthermore, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by penetrating arteries.

C) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery typically causes left-sided weakness and, if the right hemisphere is nondominant (most individuals), hemineglect. In some, typically left-handed individuals, the language center is located in the right hemisphere. In these patients, a right middle cerebral artery stroke could cause Broca aphasia. However, left-sided, not right-sided, weakness would be expected in this scenario.

D) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries that supply the left posterior limb of the internal capsule can result in right-sided weakness, as seen in this patient. However, Broca aphasia localizes to the inferior frontal gyrus of the left hemisphere, which is not supplied by penetrating arteries.

E) INCORRECT:

Dissection of the right vertebral artery can cause ischemia to brain regions supplied by the posterior circulation (e.g., cerebellum, brainstem, occipital cortex). However, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, while right-sided weakness indicates a lesion to the left precentral gyrus, both of which are supplied by the left anterior circulation.

F) CORRECT:

Broca aphasia is caused by damage of the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (typically left) hemisphere. This patient additionally has right facial droop, right-sided muscle weakness, and right-sided pronator drift downwards, suggesting an upper motor neuron lesion in the left motor cortex. The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the inferior frontal gyrus, as well as the motor cortex. This patient has several risk factors for arteriosclerosis and, therefore, ischemic stroke (hypertension, age > 65 years, diabetes mellitus), making occlusion of the left MCA the most likely cause of his focal neurologic deficits.

Ischemic strokes do not typically cause headaches, whereas hemorrhagic strokes usually manifest with severe headaches.
Image Description:

A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:

– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

G) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhage into the right posterior limb of the internal capsule due to rupture of a right posterior cerebral artery malformation could cause left-sided, but not right-sided weakness. Rupture of this artery would also cause left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, which is not present in this patient. Further, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

H) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which presents with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Broca aphasia and right-sided weakness are not consistent with lateral medullary syndrome.

I) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhage into the left posterior limb of the internal capsule due to rupture of a left posterior cerebral artery malformation could cause right-sided hemiparesis, as seen in this patient. However, rupture of this artery would also cause right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, which is not present here. Further, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.

J) INCORRECT:

Dissection of the left vertebral artery can cause ischemia to brain regions supplied by the posterior circulation (e.g., cerebellum, brainstem, occipital cortex). However, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, while right-sided weakness indicates a lesion to the left precentral gyrus, both of which are supplied by the left anterior circulation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with sudden-onset focal neurologic deficits that are consistent with stroke. Telegraphic speech (as evidenced by the use of short, simple sentences), intact comprehension (as evidenced by the ability to follow commands), and impaired repetition of word sequences are consistent with Broca aphasia. The presence of this type of language deficit helps localize the damage to a specific region of the cortex.

questions.text: An obese 37-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after the onset of weakness in her left arm and leg. She fell from the stairs the day prior but did not have any loss of consciousness or nausea after the fall. She travels to Asia regularly on business; her last trip was 4 days ago. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 113/min and regular, and blood pressure is 162/90 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased muscle strength on the left side. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the left. Babinski sign is present on the left. The right lower leg is swollen, erythematous, and tender to palpation. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects (VSD) are the most common congenital heart defect and may cause paradoxical embolism. However, VSDs typically self-resolve during childhood or are surgically repaired. VSDs make up ∼ 10% of adult congenital heart defects.

B) INCORRECT:

Carotid dissection can occur at any age and is a common cause of stroke in young patients (∼ 20% of cases). Cervical artery dissection classically manifests with headache and neck pain following exertion (e.g., exercise, sexual intercourse, or even sneezing). This patient's lack of headache or neck pain in the presence of symptoms suggesting DVT makes another etiology more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a very common cause of thromboembolic stroke in elderly individuals and those with heart disease (e.g., heart failure). Although a single normal heart rhythm on physical examination does not rule out paroxysmal AF, this patient's age and absence of heart disease mean that she is at low risk for AF.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve vegetations are seen in infective endocarditis (IE), which may embolize to the brain and cause a stroke. Although IE can manifest with low-grade fever and tachycardia, this patient does not have other typical findings, such as a new-onset heart murmur and extracardiac symptoms (e.g., splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions). Moreover, IE is unlikely in patients without risk factors, e.g., recent dental procedure, IV drug use, active untreated bacterial infection.

E) CORRECT:

A right-to-left cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect) allows paradoxical emboli originating from the venous system to pass directly from the right atrium into the left atrium, from which point they may enter the cerebral arterial system. In a young patient, stroke symptoms (e.g., unilateral weakness, hyperreflexia, facial droop) and signs of DVT should raise concern for paradoxical embolism. This patient should have an immediate stroke workup (e.g., noncontrast head CT, possible thrombolysis). Furthermore, ultrasonography should be performed to confirm DVT. Because paradoxical embolism is a diagnosis of exclusion, all other causes must be excluded after the patient has been stabilized. Given the risk of pulmonary embolism and recurrent cerebral emboli, this patient should be started on anticoagulant therapy once cerebral hemorrhage is ruled out.

Suspected patent foramen ovale should be confirmed with echocardiography so that it can be surgically or percutaneously closed to prevent recurrent emboli.
Image Description:

In the presence of a patent foramen ovale, transient increases in right atrial pressure (e.g., when coughing) can allow emboli from the venous system to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium. From there, they can enter systemic arterial circulation and cause arterial embolism (e.g., stroke).

F) INCORRECT:

Long bone fractures (particularly of the femur) can cause fat embolism. Fat embolism typically manifests with respiratory distress and a classic (but often absent) petechial chest rash as well as neurological symptoms (e.g., focal deficits as in this patient). While this patient had a recent fall, she has no indication of a femoral fracture such as bruising, deformity, or swelling of the thigh and her tender and swollen lower leg is more likely due to deep vein thrombosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Primary cardiac tumors (e.g., atrial myxoma) are extremely rare (incidence < 0.1% of the population), and can sometimes embolize, causing stroke. Most patients with primary cardiac tumors experience symptoms of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, edema) due to the tumor obstructing blood flow. Additionally, patients often experience constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss). While this patient has stroke and fever, she lacks signs of heart failure. Her unilateral leg abnormalities are more suggestive of DVT.
questions.hint: This patient has swelling, erythema, and tenderness of the right lower extremity. These features, in conjunction with a history of obesity, long-distance travel, and oral contraceptive use, indicate a high risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT; Wells DVT score ≈ 3). In addition, this patient presents with clinical features of a right-sided stroke, suggesting a paradoxical embolism.

questions.text: A previously healthy 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden weakness of her right arm and leg that started 3 hours ago. She returned from a business trip to Europe 3 days ago. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 115/min and regular, and blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased muscle strength on the entire right side. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the right. Babinski sign is present on the right. The left lower leg is swollen, erythematous, and tender to palpation. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Paradoxical emboli can pass through any right-to-left shunt, but a patent foramen ovale (PFO) is the most common route. A PFO is considered an abnormal anatomical variant of the heart and is present in ∼ 25% of the general population. In addition to a stroke workup (i.e., noncontrast head CT, possible thrombolysis, etc.), this patient should also undergo compression ultrasonography to confirm DVT. Because of the risk of pulmonary embolism and recurrent cerebral emboli, this patient should be started on anticoagulant therapy once cerebral hemorrhage is ruled out and undergo echocardiography to evaluate for surgical closure of the PFO.
Image Description:

In the presence of a patent foramen ovale, transient increases in right atrial pressure (e.g., when coughing) can allow emboli from the venous system to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium. From there, they can enter systemic arterial circulation and cause arterial embolism (e.g., stroke).

B) INCORRECT:

Primary cardiac tumors (e.g., atrial myxoma) are extremely rare (incidence < 0.1%), and can sometimes embolize, causing stroke. Most patients with primary cardiac tumors do not initially present with stroke, but experience symptoms of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, edema) due to the tumor obstructing blood flow. Additionally, patients often experience constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss). While this patient has stroke and fever, she lacks signs of heart failure. Her unilateral leg abnormalities are more suggestive of DVT.

C) INCORRECT:

Embolism of septic vegetations from infective endocarditis (IE) that go to the brain can cause stroke. Patients with IE can also present with fever and tachycardia. However, IE is unlikely in patients without major risk factors for the disease (e.g., recent dental procedure, IV drug abuse, active untreated bacterial infection). This patient's warm, swollen leg could be confused with cellulitis, which would increase her risk of IE, but without a possible entry point for pathogens as in this case, a noninfectious diagnosis is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects are the most common pediatric septal defect and can cause paradoxical embolism, which has likely occurred in this patient. However, most VSDs self-resolve during childhood (and the majority of others are surgically repaired). VSDs make up ∼ 10% of congenital heart defects found in adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation is a very common cause of thromboembolic stroke in older adults and those with heart disease (e.g., heart failure). This patient is at low risk for atrial fibrillation because of her age and lack of heart disease. Also, her heart rhythm was normal on examination, which decreases the likelihood of atrial fibrillation (but does not rule it out).

F) INCORRECT:

Carotid dissection can occur at any age and is a common cause of stroke in young patients (∼ 20% of cases). Cervical artery dissection classically presents with headache and neck pain following exertion (e.g., exercise, sexual intercourse, or even sneezing). This patient's lack of headache or neck pain in the presence of symptoms suggesting DVT make another etiology more likely.
questions.hint: This patient has multiple risk factors for deep venous thrombosis (DVT), including a history of immobilization (business trip by plane), smoking, and oral contraceptive use. Now, she presents with clinical features of a left-sided stroke (e.g., right-sided weakness, hyperreflexia, positive Babinski), which in a young patient with signs of DVT (swollen, tender, erythematous left leg) should raise concern for paradoxical embolism.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of right-sided weakness for 2 hours. He has hypertension, dyslipidemia, and type 2 diabetes. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, metoprolol, amlodipine, pravastatin, and metformin. His pulse is 87/min and blood pressure is 164/98 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows right-sided weakness, facial droop, and hyperreflexia. Sensation is intact. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Stenosis of the internal carotid artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The rupture of an intracranial (berry) aneurysm would typically result in subarachnoid hemorrhage, manifesting with a sudden-onset severe headache (“worst headache of my life”), rapidly worsening nausea/vomiting, and clinical features of meningism (e.g., neck rigidity), which are not seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Lipohyalinotic thickening of penetrating cerebral vessels (e.g., lenticulostriate arteries) is the most likely cause of this patient's pure motor lacunar infarct; obliteration of the lumina of the poorly-collateralized lenticulostriate arteries leads to the infarction of the genu and anterior ⅔ of the posterior limb of the internal capsule, where motor fibers are densely packed. Chronic, uncontrolled hypertension, diabetes mellitus, smoking, and hyperlipidemia are risk factors for lipohyalinosis.

C) INCORRECT:

A stroke due to dissection of the left vertebral artery would typically result in left lateral medullary syndrome, which would manifest with right-sided weakness. However, other features, such as vertigo, ipsilateral hearing loss, ataxia, dysarthria, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, would also be evident. Patients with vertebral artery dissection usually have neck pain and/or occipital headache, which are not seen here. Furthermore, they are typically younger (mean age approx. 45 years) and often report a history of trauma or sports injury.

D) INCORRECT:

A stroke due to carotid artery stenosis is usually an ischemic cortical infarct of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) or (less commonly) anterior cerebral artery (ACA) due to atheroembolism. A left-sided cortical infarct that is large enough to cause weakness in the entire right half of the body would also have aphasia, frontal lobe defects, and/or deficits in sensation, none of which are seen here. Moreover, patients with CAS often have a history of amaurosis fugax or transient ischemic attacks and a carotid bruit on neck auscultation, which this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

An embolus from the left atrium is the most common cause of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation and usually causes large subcortical and/or cortical infarcts. Although this patient has several risk factors for atrial fibrillation, such as increased age and hypertension, he does not have evidence of atrial fibrillation (e.g., an irregularly irregular pulse). Furthermore, a left-sided cortical infarct that is large enough to cause weakness in the entire right half of the body would likely also have aphasia, frontal lobe defects, and/or deficits in sensation, none of which are seen here. This patient's isolated motor symptoms suggest a small subcortical infarct of the internal capsule.
questions.hint: This patient presents with right-sided weakness without associated sensory dysfunction, which suggests a pure motor lacunar infarct.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man undergoes a coronary artery bypass grafting. Upon regaining consciousness, he reports that he cannot see from either eye and cannot move his arms. Physical examination shows bilaterally equal, reactive pupils. A fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. An MRI of the brain shows wedge-shaped cortical infarcts in both occipital lobes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebral amyloid angiopathy is a common cause of spontaneous intracranial hemorrhage in elderly patients. Affected patients may present with recurrent transient ischemic attack-like symptoms and rapidly progressive dementia. However, amyloid angiopathy is not a common cause of watershed infarcts.

B) INCORRECT:

A ruptured saccular aneurysm causes subarachnoid hemorrhage, which can manifest with thunderclap headaches, nonreactive pupils, unconsciousness, rapidly worsening nausea, vomiting, and cardiovascular deterioration. A ruptured aneurysm is not, however, a common cause of watershed infarcts.

C) INCORRECT:

Lipohyalinosis of the cerebral vessel walls can lead to lacunar strokes within the basal ganglia. The most important predisposing factor for lipohyalinosis is chronic hypertension. A common risk factor for chronic hypertension is atherosclerosis, which this patient who received a bypass graft likely has. However, lipohyalinosis is not a common cause of watershed infarcts.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiac embolism can cause ischemic stroke that affects watershed areas. Although these emboli often lodge in the small leptomeningeal arteries over the watershed areas, it is highly unlikely that multiple microemboli concurrently block the same vessels bilaterally. Therefore, watershed infarcts caused by cardiac embolisms and their consequent associated symptoms are overwhelmingly unilateral.

E) INCORRECT:

Atherothrombosis that affects an entire area supplied by a cerebral blood vessel can manifest with unilateral stroke-like symptoms (e.g., vision loss, weakness, numbness, slurred speech). In the rare cases that atheromatous microemboli cause a watershed infarct, the infarct is typically unilateral, not bilateral.

F) CORRECT:

The most common cause of a watershed infarct is systemic hypotension, which results in decreased perfusion to the terminal areas of the vascular fields supplied by the cerebral arteries (watershed areas). Strokes with a watershed distribution are more prevalent in patients undergoing cardiac surgery as a result of global systemic hypoperfusion (especially while on cardiopulmonary bypass). These strokes are associated with poor short-term outcomes.
questions.hint: This patient's MRI of the brain shows symmetrical infarcts in the watershed regions of the brain. The infarcts occurred occipitally at the border of the posterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery, causing bilateral visual loss.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of memory loss. Three weeks ago, he had a cardiac arrest that required cardiopulmonary resuscitation and intravenous epinephrine. On mental status examination, he cannot recall objects shown to him 20 minutes earlier but vividly recalls memories from before the incident. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following structures of the brain is most likely affected?

choices.text: Internal pyramidal layer of the amygdala
External pyramidal layer of the parietal cortex

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebellar Purkinje cells are very vulnerable to ischemic insults. However, patients with ischemic damage to this group of cells would present with intention tremor, nystagmus, and ataxia.

B) INCORRECT:

Microglial cells are relatively resistant to ischemic insults because they are not as metabolically active as neurons. In fact, these macrophages are typically seen in the inflammatory reaction to cellular injury after ischemia. Strokes affecting the dorsal midbrain present with Parinaud syndrome, not memory impairment.

C) INCORRECT:

The amygdala is a complex of nuclei located in the temporal lobe, it is not composed of cellular layers like the neocortex or hippocampus. Moreover, strokes affecting the amygdala typically result in uninhibited, aggressive behavior (Kluver-Bucy syndrome).

D) INCORRECT:

The external pyramidal layer of the parietal cortex is very vulnerable to ischemic injury. However, neuronal cell death in the dominant parietal cortex would lead to Gerstmann syndrome, not anterograde amnesia as seen here.

E) CORRECT:

Damage to the pyramidal cells of the hippocampus typically leads to anterograde amnesia, as seen in this patient. The hippocampus is the brain region most vulnerable to ischemic hypoxia, and only a few minutes of ischemia can lead to irreversible damage mediated by cytotoxic glutamatergic release and uptake. Other brain regions that are particularly susceptible to ischemic insults are neocortical pyramidal cells, striatal neurons, and Purkinje cells.

F) INCORRECT:

Astroglial cells (also known as astrocytes) of the putamen are relatively resistant to ischemic injury mainly because they can use glycogen stores for anaerobic metabolism. Moreover, injury to the cells of the putamen results in impaired voluntary muscle control rather than memory loss. Following an ischemic event, astrocytes become reactive and form a glial scar (reactive gliosis).
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of an ischemic stroke following a cardiac arrest. The short-term memory loss indicates selective neuronal necrosis of a structure within the limbic system.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after the sudden onset of speech difficulties and right-sided arm and leg weakness. Examination shows paralysis and hypoesthesia on the right side, positive Babinski sign on the right, and slurred speech. A CT scan of the head shows a hyperdensity in the left middle cerebral artery and no evidence of intracranial bleeding. The patient's symptoms improve rapidly after pharmacotherapy is initiated and his weakness completely resolves. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rivaroxaban, a direct factor Xa inhibitor, is used for the prevention of ischemic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation and the treatment of venous thromboembolism, to name a few indications. Despite its prophylactic value, it has no role in the treatment of acute ischemic stroke. Hence, it is unlikely to be given to this patient with an acute ischemic stroke.

B) CORRECT:

Alteplase, a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator, is the mainstay of treatment to salvage ischemic tissue in acute ischemic stroke. This drug converts plasminogen to plasmin, which dissolves clots by degrading fibrin. Alteplase is typically administered within 4.5 hours of symptom onset but can be used later under specialist guidance. Important contraindications include acute intracranial hemorrhage, recent surgery, severe uncontrolled hypertension, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Heparin is used for the acute treatment of several conditions such as venous thromboembolism, pulmonary embolism, and STEMI. It activates antithrombin III in a manner that inhibits both thrombin and factor X. Early use of heparin in acute ischemic stroke has been associated with higher mortality and worse outcomes as compared to other anticoagulants.

D) INCORRECT:

Prasugrel, a platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor, is given to patients with acute coronary syndrome and for those undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (to prevent coronary stent thrombosis). The drug inhibits platelet aggregation by preventing the expression of Gp IIb/IIIa receptors on the platelet surface. Prasugrel is contraindicated in patients with a history of stroke or TIA because of the increased risk of significant or fatal bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist used for the prophylaxis of ischemic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation, and as treatment for patients with venous thromboembolism. It inhibits hepatic epoxide reductase, thereby blocking synthesis (recycling) of the active, reduced form of vit. K. Without reduced vit. K, γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues cannot occur, which reduces the production of active coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, as well as anticoagulatory proteins C and S. Because this drug takes days to exert and remove its clinically significant anticoagulatory effect, it is primarily used for chronic anticoagulation and has no use in the acute setting.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms in combination with the CT results (hyperdense occluded vessel) indicate an ischemic stroke caused by an obstructive lesion in the left middle cerebral artery. The drug administered can also be used to treat patients with early myocardial infarctions or unstable patients with a pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: An autopsy is performed on a 39-year-old man 5 days after he was found pulseless at his apartment by his neighbor. Examination of the brain shows liquefactive necrosis in the distribution of the right middle cerebral artery with surrounding edema. Immunophenotyping of a sample of the affected brain tissue shows numerous cells that express CD40 on their surface. On further histopathological evaluation, the morphology of these cells is not readily discernible with Nissl stain. These histological findings are most consistent with which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radial glial cells are progenitor cells that line the ventricles in the brain. Radial glial cells do not stain positive for CD40, rather for vimentin, nestin, and GFAP.

B) CORRECT:

Microglia are responsible for the removal of cellular debris and apoptotic cells in the brain parenchyma and can be seen within 3–5 days after an injury, such as in the case of the ischemic stroke seen in this patient. Following activation, microglia express CD40 and other markers, including CD11b, CD68, and CD45.

In general, all neurons and glial cells stain with Nissl stain, which is why it is useful for determining ratios or counts of neurons and glial cells but not for identifying specific cell types within that population.

C) INCORRECT:

Astrocytes are essential for reactive gliosis, which typically occurs 5–15 days after a CNS injury and is characterized by the proliferation of astrocytes, microglia, and oligodendrocytes, creating a glial scar. Astrocytes stain positive for GFAP and glutamine synthetase but not for CD40 as the cells seen in this patient's sample.

D) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrocytes are involved in reactive gliosis, which typically occurs 5–15 days after a CNS injury and is characterized by the proliferation of astrocytes, microglia, and oligodendrocytes, creating a glial scar. Oligodendrocytes stain positive for platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha and SOX10 but not for CD40 as the cells seen in this patient's sample.

E) INCORRECT:

Neurons may be present in the sample of this patient's brain tissue, but they would stain positive for CD45 and GFAP, not for CD40.

F) INCORRECT:

Schwann cells are neural crest-derived cells that are responsible for the myelination of peripheral nerves. They are not part of the CNS and would therefore not be expected to be present in this patient's histologic sample. Moreover, they Schwann cells stain positive for S100 but not for CD40.
questions.hint: These CD40 positive cells in the brain are derived from the mesoderm and are activated in response to tissue damage. The gross findings present on autopsy suggest an ischemic stroke as a cause of his death.

questions.text: An 87-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit after a neighbor found her lying on the floor at her home. Her respirations are 13/min and shallow. Despite appropriate therapy, the patient dies. Gross examination of the brain at autopsy shows neovascularization and liquefactive necrosis without cavitation in the distribution of the left middle cerebral artery. Histological examination of a brain tissue sample from the left temporal lobe shows proliferation of neural cells that stain positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein. Based on these findings, approximately how much time has most likely passed since the initial injury in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's histological examination shows astrocyte proliferation and neovascularization. Reactive gliosis, which is characterized by astrocyte proliferation, is the attempt of brain tissue to fill the necrotic area with glial cells. These histological examination findings are usually seen 1–2 weeks after ischemic brain injury.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a brain biopsy sample (H&E stain)

Numerous deeply staining nuclei surrounded by unstained areas are visible throughout the microscopic field. This “naked nuclei” appearance is characteristic of astrocytes on an H&E stain.

Astrocytic proliferation and hypertrophy (astrocytosis) indicate reactive gliosis (or CNS scarring), which occurs secondary to CNS injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Initial cellular changes can be seen approximately 12 hours after an ischemic stroke. Findings would include red neurons caused by cytoplasmic eosinophilia. Reactive gliosis, which is seen here at autopsy, is typically not present at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Although astrocyte proliferation can still be found 25 days after an ischemic stroke, histological examination at this point would also show glial scarring with cerebral cavitation, which is not seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Initial cellular changes include electrolyte diffusion alterations, which can be radiologically detected as early as 3 minutes after the initial injury (e.g., with diffusion-weighted MRI). However, histological changes like the ones seen here at autopsy are typically not present 2 hours after injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Common histological findings 2 days after ischemic brain injury include cell necrosis and the infiltration of neutrophils. Neovascularization, which is seen here at autopsy, is typically not present at this time.
questions.hint: This patient has had a massive ischemic stroke. The GFAP-positive cells described here are most likely astrocytes, which are derived from the neuroectoderm.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with atrial fibrillation is brought to the emergency department by his wife 6 hours after the acute onset of right arm weakness and slurred speech. An MRI of the brain shows a thrombus in the left middle cerebral artery. Twelve hours later, the patient develops ventricular tachycardia. Despite appropriate care, he dies. Which of the following histopathologic changes are most likely to be seen on a biopsy specimen from the affected brain tissue?

choices.text: Glial scarring with fibrous tissue hypertrophy
Eosinophilic neuronal cytoplasm with pyknotic nuclei
Microglial infiltration with local tissue destruction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neutrophilic infiltration with central necrosis is seen on histopathologic examination of brain tissue taken 1–3 days after ischemic stroke. This patient's stroke occurred < 24 hours ago.

B) INCORRECT:

Reactive gliosis (due to activation of astrocytes and microglia) with vascular proliferation (due to the release of proinflammatory cytokines, chemokines, and VEGF in necrotic brain tissue) is seen on histopathologic examination of brain tissue taken 5–15 days after ischemic stroke. This patient's stroke occurred approximately 18 hours ago.

C) INCORRECT:

Glial scarring with fibrous tissue hypertrophy is seen on histopathologic examination of brain tissue taken > 2 weeks after ischemic stroke. This patient's stroke occurred approximately 18 hours ago.

D) CORRECT:

In patients who have had an ischemic stroke, the tissue changes seen on histopathologic examination of brain tissue depend on the time of presentation following ischemia. Within 12–24 hours after ischemia, histopathologic examination shows neurons with eosinophilic cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei. Hypereosinophilia causes a red appearance on hematoxylin-eosin staining of affected tissue, which gives the appearance of red neurons.

E) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of macrophages (microglia) with local tissue destruction is seen on histopathologic examination of brain tissue taken 3–5 days after ischemic stroke. This patient's stroke occurred < 24 hours ago.

F) INCORRECT:

Up to 12 hours after ischemic stroke, histopathologic examination of brain tissue can appear normal. This patient's stroke occurred > 12 hours ago.
questions.hint: This patient died 18 hours after developing an ischemic stroke, which is a common complication of atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the emergency department 40 minutes after a sudden loss of vision in his right eye and numbness of his left arm. He was eating dinner with his wife when he abruptly dropped his knife and felt what he describes as “like a curtain falling over my right eye.” These symptoms resolved spontaneously 15 minutes later and he says that he feels well now. He has poorly-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications are ramipril, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and insulin. He is alert and fully oriented. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 136/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. On neurologic examination, muscle strength is 5/5 throughout. Sensation is intact bilaterally. His serum glucose concentration is 180 mg/dL. ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Neuroimaging is indicated for all patients with suspected TIA within 24 hours of presentation to rule out stroke. Diffusion-weighted MRI is the preferred imaging modality because it shows even small ischemic changes within 30 minutes after onset (while a CT scan shows changes only after 6–24 hours) and can differentiate acute from chronic lesions. If MRI is not available, a CT scan of the head can be performed. Besides neuroimaging, antiplatelet therapy should be initiated urgently because TIA is associated with a high risk of subsequent stroke. If TIA is confirmed, further workup to identify the underlying etiology is indicated. This workup includes neurovascular imaging to assess arterial causes (e.g., carotid Doppler ultrasound for carotid artery stenosis) and, in patients with suspected embolic source or unknown TIA etiology, cardiac evaluation (e.g., ECG, transthoracic ultrasonography). In addition, secondary prevention of TIA, including lifestyle modifications (e.g., smoking cessation) and management of chronic diseases (e.g., hypertension, diabetes mellitus), should be initiated.

In patients with persistent neurologic symptoms (i.e., patients with suspected stroke), the diagnostic workup for stroke should be initiated immediately. A noncontrast CT scan of the head is then indicated to rule out intracranial hemorrhage prior to further management (e.g., thrombolysis).

B) INCORRECT:

Carotid duplex ultrasonography can be used in the diagnostic workup of TIA to visualize arterial causes (e.g., carotid artery stenosis). This step may be indicated at a later point, but an important and urgent differential of TIA has not yet been excluded in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

All patients with suspected TIA should receive certain testing to rule out differential diagnoses that require urgent management. This patient's pulse oximetry, serum blood glucose levels, and ECG are normal, but a stroke has not been excluded yet. After the exclusion of differentials, further management to determine the etiology of TIA is indicated. In addition, all patients with TIA should receive antiplatelet therapy at the time of the diagnosis. Reassessment in 24 hours is therefore not an appropriate management approach at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography can be used in the diagnostic workup for TIA for cardiac evaluation in patients with suspected embolic source or unknown etiology. This step may be indicated at a later point, but an important and urgent differential of TIA has not yet been excluded in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

CT angiography (CTA) of the neck can be used in the diagnostic workup of TIA to visualize arterial causes (e.g., carotid artery stenosis). This step may be indicated at a later point, but an important differential diagnosis of TIA has not yet been excluded in this patient.
questions.hint: Acute focal neurologic symptoms (unilateral sensory deficits, amaurosis fugax) that resolve spontaneously within 15 minutes are consistent with a transient ischemic attack (TIA).

questions.text: Two days after being admitted for an ischemic stroke of the left middle cerebral artery, a 74-year-old woman is evaluated for worsening confusion. She received intravenous alteplase therapy and was admitted to the intensive care unit. Twenty-four hours after being admitted, the patient started antiplatelet therapy; she was already able to speak in full sentences and had slightly improved muscle function. While being evaluated by the physical therapist this morning, the patient was confused. Her pulse is 72/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/64 mm Hg. She does not respond to verbal commands but withdraws appropriately to painful stimuli. Neurologic examination shows equal and reactive pupils. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hemorrhagic transformation (HT) is a common complication of ischemic stroke and typically manifests with neurologic deterioration (e.g., new confusion, worsening neurological deficits) within 24–48 hours of the inciting ischemic event. The risk of hemorrhagic transformation is significantly increased in patients who have received thrombolytic medications (e.g., alteplase), antiplatelet therapy (e.g., aspirin, clopidogrel), and/or thrombosis prophylaxis (e.g., heparin, enoxaparin). Other risk factors for HT include hyperglycemia, hypertension, advanced age, delayed initiation of reperfusion therapy, and large infarct size. Measures that can reduce the rate of HT include neuroprotective measures (e.g., tight blood pressure and glycemic control, targeted temperature management) and careful preselection of patients eligible for thrombolytic therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Cerebral vasospasm is a complication of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which typically occurs 4–14 days after the inciting event and would cause neurologic deterioration. Cerebral vasospasm is not, however, a complication of ischemic stroke.

C) INCORRECT:

Recurrent ischemic stroke can manifest with neurologic deterioration after a period of stabilization or improvement after ischemic injury. However, this patient has received thrombolytic therapy (alteplase) and has already been started on antiplatelet therapy, both of which significantly reduce the likelihood of recurrent ischemic stroke. A different complication of ischemic stroke is more likely in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Uncal herniation can manifest with neurologic deterioration but would also cause pupillary changes (e.g., ipsilateral mydriasis) and signs of cardiorespiratory compromise (e.g., bradycardia, apnea), none of which is seen here.
questions.hint: This condition occurs as a result of reperfusion injury, which leads to endothelial damage and disruption of the blood-brain barrier.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman hospitalized for Escherichia coli pyelonephritis is improving with the use of ampicillin when she experiences sudden onset of left-sided face, arm, and leg weakness. She reports no chest pain or shortness of breath.
Physical examination reveals findings consistent with an acute left hemiplegia and atrial fibrillation but is otherwise unremarkable. There are no carotid bruits.
The patient has been taking warfarin for atrial fibrillation for the past 20 years; her most recent international normalized ratio was 2.6. Results from a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and complete blood count are unremarkable.
CT of the head shows mild brain atrophy consistent with the patient’s age and no acute hemorrhage.
The patient is found to be hypertensive when vital signs are obtained in the first few hours after the onset of neurologic symptoms, and initiation of an antihypertensive medication is being considered.
What is the lowest blood pressure above which antihypertensive medications should be considered in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient has symptoms consistent with acute stroke, and CT has ruled out a hemorrhage as the cause. Given that she is taking warfarin and her international normalized ratio is >1.7, she cannot undergo intravenous thrombolysis. Her symptoms should therefore be managed medically.

Blood pressure is frequently elevated after a stroke, which is thought to optimize perfusion to areas distal to the arterial occlusion. In fact, the lowering of blood pressure in the acute setting has been associated with clinical deterioration, and a permissive approach to blood-pressure control immediately after a stroke is therefore recommended.

Current guidelines permit initiation of antihypertensive therapy if the blood pressure exceeds 220/120 mm Hg, although the benefit of initiating or reinstating antihypertensive treatment in the first 48 to 72 hours is uncertain. In a patient who is not a candidate for thrombolysis, it is generally reasonable to set a goal blood-pressure reduction of 15% in the first 24 hours, unless the patient has other strong indications for blood-pressure lowering (e.g., decompensated heart failure).

Of note, a blood pressure >185/110 mm Hg is itself a contraindication to thrombolytic therapy. If a patient is otherwise a candidate for thrombolysis, the recommendation is to lower the blood pressure to <185/110 mm Hg so that thrombolytic therapy may be administered safely.

Key learning point: In patients with acute ischemic stroke who are not candidates for intravenous thrombolysis, antihypertensive therapy should be considered only if the blood pressure exceeds 220/120 mm Hg.

B) INCORRECT:

Current guidelines permit initiation of antihypertensive therapy if the blood pressure exceeds 220/120 mm Hg, although the benefit of initiating or reinstating antihypertensive treatment in the first 48 to 72 hours is uncertain. In a patient who is not a candidate for thrombolysis, it is generally reasonable to set a goal blood-pressure reduction of 15% in the first 24 hours, unless the patient has other strong indications for blood-pressure lowering (e.g., decompensated heart failure).

Of note, a blood pressure >185/110 mm Hg is itself a contraindication to thrombolytic therapy. If a patient is otherwise a candidate for thrombolysis, the recommendation is to lower the blood pressure to <185/110 mm Hg so that thrombolytic therapy may be administered safely.

C) INCORRECT:
